moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6: The starting position for all the games.
moves.8. c3 d5 9. d3 dxe4 10. dxe4 Bg4 11. h3: It took a while, but development is finally complete and the game starts taking shape.
moves.17... a4 18. Ba2 Bd6 19. Kh1 Ne7 20. Nc4: After some maneuvering, I threaten to exchange off Black's remaining Bishop, which would leave me with the much better pair of minor pieces.
moves.20... Ng6 21. Nxd6 cxd6 22. Rxd6: I gain a Pawn in the mix-up
moves.22... Ra6 23. Rxa6: Up a pawn and with 2 B's vs. 2 Knights on an open board, I'm definitely not averse to exchanging major pieces.
I sacrifice a minor exchange with the intent of winning a second Pawn [Black's KP].
In the confusion, I overlook that Black can win the Exchange. Now material is even, but my passed QP gives me an advantage.
moves.30... f6 31. Bd6: Keeping the initiative by attacking the Rook.
moves.31... Rd8 32. Qe6+: Now I've finally guarded my passed Pawn, and still maintain the initiative with a check.
moves.32... Kh8 33. Qf7: Trying to set up a mate on the cornered King.
moves.33... Qxb2 34. Bf8: I willingly give up the QNP to threaten mate in 1. Black's Q is now forced to defend his KN2, restricting its movements severely.
moves.34... f5 35. d6: In the meantime, with the Q tied down, I press my passed Pawn menacingly forward.
moves.35... Qd4 36. Qe7: Black could rid himself of the menacing Pawn with 36... RxP 37 QxR, but I would have a technically easy win with my piece ahead.
moves.37... Kg8 38. Qe8: If Black tries 38... Q-Q4 guarding the R and keeping the Queening square doubly guarded, I force his hand with 39 B-K7 dis ch.
moves.38... Rxe8 39. dxe8=Q: Not only do I win the Rook, I also threaten to win at once with 40 B-B5 dis ch simultaneously attacking the Q.
moves.39... Qc4 40. Bb4+: I secure my B and QRP while maintaining the initiative.
moves.40... Kh7 41. Qxa4: Now I have yet another passed Pawn.
moves.42... Qxf2+ 43. Kh1: With my King in the corner, I have to be careful. At a minimum Black is seeking a perpetual check for a draw, and with the Q's still on the board, it's certainly possible.
moves.43... Qxg3 44. Qd7: I'm looking to regenerate my mating threat on KN7.
moves.44... Qxh3+ 45. Kg1: Black has succeeded in eradicating my K-side Pawns.
moves.45... h5 46. Bf8: The mating threat again restricts the movement of the Black Q.
moves.46... Qg4+ 47. Kh2: As good a spot as any.
moves.47... h4 48. a4: I can advance the Pawn freely since Black's Q is tied to defending KN2.
moves.49... h3 50. Qb7: Now *Black* has a mating threat at *my* KN2. Dueling potential mates...
moves.50... f4 51. a5: We both push on our Pawns.
moves.51... f3 52. Qxg7+: I'm forced to do this, since the Black KBP has cut my Q's access to KN2 on the diagonal.
moves.52... Qxg7 53. Bxg7: Black misses a golden opportunity. 53... P-B7!!! wins at once, as I cannot stop the P from Queening. But he is blinded by greed.
moves.53... Kxg7 54. Kg1: Now my K is in position to capture either Black pawn if it advances, and Black's K is too far away to prevent to promotion of my QRP.
moves.54... Kg6 55. a6: Black rushes his K forward to try and force through a Pawn, but he's one tempo behind.
moves.56... Kg4 57. a8=Q: If the Black K were already at KN6, he could check with a Pawn and at least have an opportunity to force one through. But...
moves.57... Kg3 58. Qg8+: Now as long as I continually harass the K, the Black Pawns cannot move.
moves.58... Kh4 59. Qh7+: I'm hoping to move the Q steadily forward and through a series of checks win the two Black Pawns.
moves.60... Kf4 61. Qf6+: Black has to move his K away from the Pawns. Instead, he plays a natural-looking move, trying to keep both Pawns protected...
moves.61... Kg3 62. Qg5#: ...and stumbles into this beautiful epaulette mate!

opening: Ruy Lopez (C86), Worrall attack, sharp line
